timeline.bodyText: IMHO there is no need to include the id in the response payload. What should a protocol adapter do with it?
timeline.author: sophokles73

   "secrets": [{
+    "id": "349556ea-4902-47c7-beb0-1009ab693fb4",

replies.bodyText: Indeed, the adapters don't have any use of this. I made a mistake by editing that file ! I reverted the changes

replies.bodyText: the ID property of the secret is provided here so the user can keep track of the different secrets without handing over the actual values. I also thought the id property could be provided in the payload to a PUT request on the management API if the user need to update this specific secret. (without creating another one, or submitting all of the other credentials, but that is not implemented yet) .
replies.author: jbtrystram

replies.bodyText:
I actually meant the empty pwd-plain property ...
So, if I get it right, then the id property currently has no purpose at all because it is not considered when adding/updating credentials, right?
replies.author: sophokles73

replies.bodyText:
Indeed, the pwd-plain  does not have any sense here. removed.
the id field still have a use IMHO. When the user set some credentials, he can "verify" they are in the registry with receiving an id for each password. I think if I don't know hono very well I would be confused if I received an empty secrets array after registering a hashed password. With the id field I know the password is there.
replies.author: jbtrystram

timeline.bodyText: I would rather keep the original wording and instead explain explicitly, why the response payload does not contain the password itself ...

- * The device registry credentials endpoint will no longer handout details for hashed-password secrets.
-   Each password is given an ID which is now returned by the device registry.
+ * The device registry credentials endpoint will no longer handout sensitive details for hashed-password secrets.
+   `pwd-hash`, `Salt` and `hash-function` are stored by the device registry but not returned to the user.
